titleStmt.title: Joseph Dalton Hooker an Alexander von Humboldt. Darjeeling, 26. April 1849

editionStmt.p: Joseph Dalton Hooker an Alexander von Humboldt. Darjeeling, 26. April 1849, hg. v. Sabine Seifert. In: edition humboldt digital, hg. v. Ottmar Ette. Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften, Berlin. Version 11 vom 04.06.2025. URL: https://edition-humboldt.de/v11/

physDesc.p: Dieser Brief enthält einen Notizzettel Alexander von Humboldts, der auf der ersten Seite des Briefes angeklebt wurde und hier als Blatt 1 ediert ist. Die Unterstreichungen im Brief stammen von Hooker, aber auch von Humboldt.

div.p:
Your long & most welcome
letter arrived when I was in
travelling
in Nepal & was not received by me
for many weeks after its arrival here. On
my return from to
Darjiling Mr. Hodgson
had left the station on account of his
health & it was only on my joining
him last month in the Terai that
I could talk with him about the
contents of your letter. In the first place
he desires me to thank you with the
greatest warmth & sincerity for the
kind & prompt attention you have paid given to
our request ,
the long letter you have written, the great
compliment thus paid to us, & above all
for the admirable & unexceptionable
plan you & Prof. Professor
Berghaus have drawn
out. You cannot conceive what a
load of trouble this has taken off our
hands, nor what a prized memorial it
will ever be, not only to ourselves, but to
the country, for whose benefit the charts
are planned. That this first attempt
to instruct the youth of India in physical
science, & in their own tongue, should
be grounded on a plan of Baron Hum
boldt’s, gives a character to the undertaking
that nothing else could. Believe us
we never expected you to have paid such attention
to the subject .
& that in doing so you
have done us the happiest service. The
work shall go forth as the offspring of
Baron Humboldt ’ s matured experience, &
I am sure that it will not be felt
unworthy of you my kind friend, after
so many years of usefulness in other & spheres
& countries to have your name so
prominently associated with the an
undertaking which under whatever
difficulties must succeed in India.

I wrote shortly to Prof. Professor
Berghaus,
requesting him to delay till we should
hear whether the Govt: Government would wish
to take any part in & propose any
alterations to the plan. This they
do not & as nothing it appears to us
can be better than the proposal plan you
& Prof. Professor
Berghaus have made we think
it the details better left wholly to the judgement
of that distinguished & experienced man.
The moneymoney is lodged with my Father
to be remitted exactly as you propose
& I shall write by this mail to Prof. Professor
B. Berghaus
again. I wish the sum could be larger,
I am sure Prof. Professor
B. Berghaus deserves that it should,
but Mr. Hodgson is no longer in the
service, & our private means are limited.

Regarding your questions as to the
heights of the great Himal Himalaya Peaks:

1. Kanchain (Kunchin- or Kinchin-)-junga
is considerably the loftiest hitherto
determined with accuracy & the
elevations are

Gossain? than? & Kanchain – seen both
from Nepal valley & thence called
“Deodangha” & also from Sikkim.
This has never been measured
till
since my last letter to you
nor even laid down on charts –
but which Col. Colonel
Waugh considers
as probably a very little higher
than either Kanchain or Dawalgari.

4. Of Jawari I can give you no further
information at all. Under any
circumstances it ranks as a second
class Peak in point of mere elevation.

To conclude I have given you exactly all I
know. I wish it were more definite
but Col: Colonel
Waugh looks upon an error
of a foot in mensuration, as of more
importance than I do – & it he speaks &
writes with all the doubts I have given
you above. He concludes that there
can be but little difference between
Dawalgari, Deodhanga & Kanchain – that
no other Peaks approach these, that all
IIexceed 28000 Engl. English feet. – Curious as is
the problem of height, the most interesting
to me is the position of the dominant masses;
whether of great in mean elevation of their mass or
actual height of a particular spire is
of less consequence. For it is where the
great accumulations of Perp Perpetual Snow are,
that the watersheds will head. There
are between Long Longitude 80° & 9 8 0 °. 1 .
º Jawar. 2º
Dawalgri. 3º Gossain than

Peaks of not accurately measured in
Bhothan. Mr Hodgson demonstrates
that the great
SubHimal SubHimalayan rivers have
their sources in these, that there came
the waters of the opposing faces of 2 contiguous
Peaks to converge to meet in the
generally
in the SubHimal SubHimalaya & form Deltic basins ; .
By means of these basins we propose to
divide the whole Himal. Himalaya Geographically,
Ethnograph. Ethnographically ,
Zoolog. Zoologically & Botanically. Sikkim
for instance is the basin of the Teesta
where East feeders rise from Kinchan
& are pushed all to the East, so as almost
to meet the waters of the Chumalari
which are pushed West. Further West
of this you will observe that the
waters from the opposite faces of the
contiguous Peaks meet within the
SubHimal SubHimalaya – here they do not; but
still between the grand South spur of
Kinchin (Singalelah) which runs from
its summit to the plains, & the grand
South spur of Chumalari which is
also continuous to the plains, – all is
one water shed. To explain this I
send you a small sketch plan which
will also help to illustrate my recent
tour in the mountains.

Unfortunately the season of 1848 was so
bad & the Sikkim Rajah so strenuously
opposed my visiting Kunchin in Sikkim
that I was obliged to put off starting
till the very end of October & take a
circuitous route in Nepal. Thus I was
led to two Thibet Passes – the Eastermost
of there in Nepal & to a fair exami
nation of the NW Northwest , W. West ,
SW. Southwest & latterly the
S. South limits of Perp. Perpetual Snow upon the
great mountain. My chart is
hardly finished & as you may suppose
the labor of such a work amongst
mountains wherein known points
are never visible is great.

Starting W. West from Darjeeling I crossed
the Singalelah spur of Kinchin
at 7000 ft feet & descended to the feeders
of the MaiEventuell handelt es sich um den Mai Khola. & Myong rivers. Thence I
struck North intending to go by
the ridges to Kinchin before proceeding
W. West to the Passes – My food beare
rs
here deserted me, they were people
of Bhotan & the only ones thought to
be equally fitted for the hot valleys
& the Mts Mountains . I ha
d thus to wait patiently
till the middle of Novr. November on a Mt Mountain of
11000 ft feet when I employed myself in
Met. Observ. Meteorological Observations & Botany . , sending out my
remaining people to the distant villages
for coolies. With Enough of them to
carry my necessaries & leaving the food,
I struck W. West amongst deep Gorges (3000 ft feet
above sea) & ascended a very lofty
transverse ridge from Singalelah of 11000
ft. feet seeking a way to the Tambur river
along which the E. East high road from Ilam
to Walloong on the Thibet frontier runs.

Reaching that river when only 2500 ft feet
above the sea I ascended it getting
foo t d as best we could & carrying a
tropical vegetation up to amongst
those spurs of Kinchin which are Perp. Perpetually
snowed. I arrived at the limits of
rice cultivation & Hinduism & the
commencement of a temperate zone
& Bhothia inhabitants .
on the 25 Novr. November – The change was
sudden from BubalusDer Asiatische Büffel (Bubalus) ist eine Untergattung der Rinder (Bovini), im Süden und Südosten Asiens verbreitet. & Rice to
BosDas Eigentliche Rind (Bos) ist eine Untergattung der Rinder (Bovini), in Asien und Nordamerika verbreitet. & corn. Still ascending to
Walloong by stupendous gorges, the
third 2nd change from Bos to Bison (the
Yak, whose progenitor is the wild
Bison {non descript} of the Thibet plan)
was mere gradual. Walloong is the
cis Himal. Himalayan commercial entrepot of the
Bhotheas. Here I was received with
suspicion & every obstacles to my
proceeding to the Passes organized, the
more effectually as the season was
very late & food was witheld withheld . Happily
I had a dozen Bhotan men still
with me, a set of villains feared by
all the Mt: Mountain powers, & by dint of
bullying the authorities & threatening
to let the Bhotan men loose upon
their store houses, I was allowed to
proceed after 2 days delay to the Pass.

Walloong village is about 11000 ft. feet , the
Pass, 1½ days beyond, & is about 12 miles
North
WNW West North West
of Kinchin top & 25 from the
latter – We reached the summit in
two days, with much difficulty, the
III aground deeply covered with October
snow at 12000 ft feet , which at 13000
does not melt till March following.
The summit was 16700 ft feet , but still
3 marches from the Plain of Thibet
which is here cut off by 2 lofty
ranges, spurs of Kinchin, projecting
NW. Northwest on that plain of lower elevation
than my position, but cut off by now
heavily snowed valleys. I could not
get one coolie to the top of the pass
& at this season to have proceeded to
Thibet without Yaks would be
impossible were even there no Chinese
guard at the foot of the 3.d range.
As near as I could ascertain the Perp. Perpetual
snow line is here 14500 ft feet & from what
I afterwards saw I still think this is
not underestimated but with such
a mash as the October fall it is quite
impossible to speak accurately.

This not being the Easternmost Pass
over the range into Thibet, & ergo not
the nearest accessible point to Kinchin
top in E. East
Nepal . , I determined on
my return to Walloong to visit the
valley E. East of this whence a loftier pass,
hardly used, leads to Thibet – Descending
the Tambur I turned up the Yangma
valley which expanded into a
broad treeless gorge full of Lake beds.
The Lake beds are confined by enormous
dams of rock which have been
projected across the valley when the
whole was under water. When in
short the Thibet plain was accumulating
its deposits of Gravel (1000 ft feet thick
have been measured in W. West
Thibet)
the waters standing at 15000 in the
Yangma valley have left on the
flanks of that valley parallel roads
as beautiful as those of Glen Roy in
Scotland. Lateral gulleys have floated
rocks into the valley upon Bergs
bridging it completely across, so
that on the retirement of the waters
these bridges formed dams. The
Terraces are on both sides the valley
above the Lake beds, are perfectly
parallel, rise in steppes along the
steep Mt. Mountain faces .
& are every where
strewed with enormous blocks of
rock – In these lateral glacial valleys
small patches of glacial Ice now
alone are found .
& the gravel &
rubbish are disposed by them, as the
enormous blocks (20 yds long) were by
the greater Ice action in past eras.

I have planned the valley & shewn that
these bridges across the valley, a mile
long, one 800 ft feet high & all of blocks
of rock too irregularly piled for vegetation,
are the true effects of Berg Ice floating
from the lateral valleys out of which
they stream. These stupendous monuments
of glacial action admit of no other explanation
& the many particulars so reminded me
of the shores of the Antarct. Antarctic Ocean that I
feel no doubts of the justness of my
conclusions. Yangma village, at the
forked head of the broad valley, is above
the limits of shrubs even, it occupies
the flanks of a flat topped terrace of rubbish & stones
which is 300 ft feet above the
floor of the valley 2 miles
long & dead flat at top. Schematische Zeichnung des Flußtales des Yangma Khola, desYangma sowie der angrenzenden Hügel und Terrassen, von Joseph Dalton Hooker in Tinte.
A series of small terraces
flank the river. The
village is 13700 ft feet above
the sea (2 Bars. Barometers
& boiling points)
& there are crops of wheat
Pease & radishes; reaped
in September. Thence I turned
E East
NW. Northwest
one day’s march to the
Kanglachem pass to Thibet but
had great difficulty in attaining 16000
ft feet owing to the depth of the Snow.
3 more dry Lake beds up this valley (8 in
all) were of precisely the same origin
as these below the village. The upper
at 16000 ft feet was full of Snow surrounded
on all sides by glacier Mts. Mountains . I effected
such a survey of these phenomena as
I could in the depth of winter & with
so short an allowance of food .
&
returned down the valley but not
to the Tambur river - Opposition was
still rife & I determined to attempt
the passage return into Sikkim over 3
intervening shoulders of Kinchin
The first but could only procure
7 days food for each of my 15 men
which we carried with our loads
upon our backs. From the Yangma
valley we crossed S.W. South West the Nango
shoulder of Kinchin at 15760 ft. feet , it
was very heavily snowed & the coolies
getting frost bitten, we were benighted
& had to camp just below the opposite
summit. This spur rises in Nango
Mt Mountain to about 21000 ft. feet & we crossed
close below that Mt Mountain
. ,
D d escended to
the Kambachen valleyDer Kambachen, auch Kangbachen, ist ein Nebengipfel des Kangchendzönga. a tremendous
gorge, to the small village where we
III bwere kindly received by the Bhotheas
who were unable to afford us any
addition to our provisions as they daily
expected to be Snowed up (about 12 0 5 00 ft feet )
& the winter’s fall is often 15 feet: here
too they cultivate wheat, Pease & radishes.
I found the Larch a Larix & 10 species
of Rhododendron in the valley, of the latter
genus I have now 20 Sikkim species.
The glacial ridges were as wonderful
here as in Yangma valley. Hence we
proceeded to cross another shoulder
of Kinchin called Choonjerma, which
took us 3 days. Jummo the great Peak of this ridge is 25311 ft feet above sea. We
crossed its shoulder at 15 0 3 00 ft feet & 8 miles from
the top. The pass is double heavily
snowed & very bad, we were again
benighted on the crest but a young
moon le t d us to b eyond the Snow to camp.

From this we descended to the
Yalloong valley intending to go up it
to the Yalloong village & thence cross
the great Southern Spur of Kinchin
(called Singalelah) into Sikkim.
To our distress for we had but one
day’s more food the village was
found deeply buried in Snow & the
inhabitants had fled to the nearest
villages in Nepal. To cross Singalelah
from hence, where it could not be
less than 18000 ft feet , was impossible & we
hence ,
had no choice but to follow
the valley down S.W. South West & seek the
first villages – which we reached
on the thir
d day in great distress.

To get again into Sikkim was now my
object & we continued South crossing
every lateral spur from Singalelah till
the end of Decb. December when we found a long
deserted path by which the Ghorkhas
had ravaged Sikkim many years ago –
Food was very scarce but we got
5 days of rice & opening a path through
the jungle with great toil reached the
top of the range at 11000 ft. feet on the third
day & descended through a heavy Snow
storm to the Western feeders of the
Teesta or Gt Great Rungeet river. From hence
I crossed the Great Rungeet (3000 feet) & S W. E
South East spur of
Kinchin to the Teesta where its bed was
only about 2000 ft feet & there met the Rajah
& my kind & dear friend Dr Campbell the Polit. Supert: Political Superintendent
of Darjiling. After so long an absence from any one
to talk to this was a real delight – He had
come by a route never travelled – The Rajah
received us with little courtesy & had put
every obstacle in the way of Dr
C. Campell s proceedings.
His poor court was wholly Lhassan & though
utterly contemptible in position he managed
to ape the Chinese dignity – I heard much news
from his people of the Thibet plain routes to
Lhassa & thence N North , N.W North West , & W West
. , all agree that the
Yarow is the Brahmap Brahmaputra . Grapes really grow at Lhassa,
it is warm for Thibet. In the S E astern
provinces of T. Thibet a rice is grown – Mulberry-silk
worn & a species of Tea .
cult. cultivated decide
d ly on this
side the Peling .
Mts. Mountains . Dr
C. Campbell returned with me
to the Gt Great Rungeet river passing two days
en route on a Mt Mountain of 12000 ft feet . Hence On the
Gt. Great Rungeet we visited & examined the oldest
Lama convents, drew & described their contents
& collected much curious information from the
Lamas who were hospitable & kind, much
revered by all the people & hold large estates.
All are Bhotheas, but a we find a wide difference
between the tribes of Bs. Bhotheas there being:
I.º the
Thibetan proper – transnivean of many tribes –
2 II.º Cisnivean Bhotheas, acknowledging their trans
nivean origin . , & there are:
1. Salt Traders of Nepal. 7–14000 ft feet
2. Sikkim Bhotheas agriculturists never living above
7000 6000 –
3. º
Lamas renewed from Thibet who
take church preferment in Sikkim.
Besides these
the
Bhotan people to the West (Bhotan is „Lho“
or „Lhop“) the name Bhotan (end of Bhote) is
unknown to themselves. „Durma People“ is their
universal appellative. These are totally difft. different in
disposition to any others .
& alto th g ether damnable.
My coolies were many of these & the most intrac
table, ungenerous, selfish cowards I ever met.

We have besides in Sikkim also of Mongolian
origin:
1. Lepchas, a charming, simple & attractive
people who live from 3–6000 ft feet , never inhabit the
same spot long, are idler than Bhotheas, worship
Demons & talk a very peculiar dialect – .
2
. & 3
.
& 4 the

As the first English travellers we were received with
great kindness by the jolly monks & friars who
gave us all their poor information on the
history of their country. Their books & institutions
alas their libraries & records had all been burned
in the Ghorkha wars & the garbled accounts they
are now drawing up will be in future the
only records of the early migrations of the Bhodist
priests into Sikkim, with they Rajah who
the simple Lepchas ,
desired from Lhassa.

Dr Campbell had hence to go South back to Darjiling
& I being very anxious to visit the S. South face of
Kinchin proceeded North. After many days
of toilsome journeys through the most impracti
cable country I camped at 14000 ft feet on the
flanks of the Great Mt. Mountain upon a bold bare
spur covered with snow & every where
abounding in evidences of great glacial floods
having once washed all over it. The ground
was frozen 16 inches but a therm. thermometer sunk 2 ft. feet
6. inches stood considerably higher –. I hoped
to have spent a week here but after 3
days of observations the snow fell so
heavily that we were obliged to retreat
with precipitancy & in the middle of January
after 2 days of great exertion descended to the
valleys at the foot of the Mt. Mountain . Thence returning
by a difft. different route I visited the sacred Lake of
Sikkim & witnessed the simple worship of
the Bhudhists. Thence to the oldest convents
in Sikkim where I staid a few days with
the monks .
& finally returned to Darjiling.

The whole of this route was over unexplored
country .
& though a stout wal
wall
k er walker
I
did not
on the average go
5 miles linear
in the day. – not one an hour though our

for 5 or 6 hours each day. My Meteorological
observations were conducted hourly from Sunrise
till 9 or 10 AM & from Sunset till 10 PM .
when
I reposed. They accord with Obs. Observations at Calcutta
& Darjiling with some intermissions. Both
Barometers behaved admirably & some of the
results in temperature of air & streams & of a
therm. thermometer sunk 2½ ft feet at many stations below
14000 ft feet will I hope prove curious. I made
copious obs. observations of the wedge glass Photometer &
black bulb .
T. Thermometer
at all elevations .
& a perfect
register of wind, sky &c – temp temperature of grass, Dew
radiation &c. Botany was however always
my first care – collecting, noting produce use,
native names (Bhothea, Ghorkha & Lepcha)
& above all Elevations for which the
Barometers or Sextant were always at
work. – My collections are very copious from
the temperate zone .
& lower Arctic where the
Rhododendrons form woods at 10-12000 ft. feet
with & above Pines. Tej ascends to 9000 ft feet ,
Parasit Orchid to 10000 with Asclep Asclepias . Cucurbit
& many other proofs of the greater elevation to
which tropical genera ascend in Sikkim than
in any other part of the world . , due greatly
I think to the uniform great elevation of
the
SubHimal. SubHimalaya & more still to the proximity
to the ocean & the prevalence of the S.E. Southeast wind
which blows over no intervening hills in
Bengal. Pines are very rare. Balanophora
ascend to 9000 ft feet – Palms to nearly 7000 ft feet ,
wild Plantain & Tree fern the same.

In Geology I have been able to do a good
deal. The and display of granite forming
the tops of all the Mts Mountains above 20000 ft feet , the
stupendous features of its outbursts along
the main range & at every flank & spur
of Kinchin are wonderfully fine. Perp. Perpetual C u l iffs of
stratified rock 4000 ft feet in measured height,
baked red & distorted like shot silk the
to a e u nparallel
e l
ed degree are traversed with
gigantic veins of Quartzose Porphyry, Eurite &c.
Detached Mt Mountain masses of the mica schists & Gneiss
are tossed up to 20000 ft. feet & all is on a scale
of confusion & grandeur that defies even
recollection. I saw no Limestone – no fossils –
Mica & clay-slate, Gneiss & Granite, here compose
the whole Himal. Himalaya with the various clays often
with 30 percent of alumina & the various endogenous
rocks varying in composition stick through the
exogenous in the grandest scale. Feldspar abounds
disproportionally in the Granite which contains
I think both Soda & Potash. Ores are rariss rarissime
. , a little
Tin, Iron, Chrome & much mangamese mangenese . I found no
fine minerals, no volcanic matter – one warm
spring of pure water – I have prepared 3 cross
sections of the
Himal Himalaya from the crest of the Mts Mountains to
the plains illustrated Physically, Geologically,
Meteorolog. Meteorologically , Botanically & Geolog Geologically
. In Magnetics &
Electricity I have done nothing. My map is very
accurate with bearings & Astron. obs. Astronomical observations for Latitude –
watches cannot go well in such countries.

On my return after packing my collections I
went to the foot of the hills, met my dear friend
Hodgson & we together explored the torrid valleys
of the Terai Botanically & Geologically keeping
up a Met. Meteorological register & tracing the Evidences of
water terraces & steppes which I now carry from
the plains up to 16000 ft feet . There I found coal (useless)
& faint traces of the tertiary deposits of the N.W. North West
Plumbago, Iron & Lime in deposits from springs.
The proofs of the gradual retirement of the waters
from the foot of the Mts Mountains are beautiful. I traced
them to 30 miles distant from the hills.

Now I am preparing for another trip to
the Snows, the Rajah’s tacit opposition & the
rains will be obstacles, but I know & like
the people & could I but get coolies who dared
to cross the Passes even 4 I would still measure
the Thibet plain at the foot of Kinchin but
Chinese vigilance is insuperable, the people though
good & courageous in all other respects dread their
Rajah & the Chinese, the former sells their family
to Bhothan slavery on the slightest pretense & I
cannot get independent people but Bhothan
men, who fear no God nor man nor JD Joseph Dalton Hooker
which is the worst part of it .
& with whom
I cannot get on. I take 4 hoping to cross the
passes & have offered all the bribes my poor
purse can command. I shall be some Months
away & hope to camp high up on the passes to
take Simultaneous Met. Meteorological
Obs. Observations with Dorjiling
& Calcutta. – I send you a sketch plan with
the approx. approximate position of the Passes I seek, Lachen
& Lachoon, the former is said to debouche on the
plain of Thibet, with no descent.
H ow very
hard it will be if I cannot get through! – How
curious is the reentrant ∠ angle that po
liti cal Thibet
makes here – still the water shed is in parallel
of Chumalari. – Food in these journeys is a great
desideratum, there is no personal danger. For
Bhotheas bully & oppose tacitly & will not fight.

Thomson has returned to Ferozepore ruined in
health I fear – my own age & brothers as we are I
deeply deplore this – his sufferings have been
great & the later ones added to the Affghan impri
sonment 8 years ago where he suffered with the worst,
have told on his once glorious constitution – he is en route
to Simlah for his health & will join me in November.
I have given up all Idea of Upper Assam, it is quite
impracti a c able. – An explorer sent thither by Hodgson has
just been murdered in cold blood & the climate is
very unhealthy. Thomson has been to Karakoram Pass
(a little too far N. North in your map.) – about 18000 ft feet
. , he
for 3 days traversed a plain of 17500 ft. feet (same as Pamir)
& probably a continuation of the great nœudNoeuds (frz.): Knoten. Gemeint sind die Berggipfel. at Koenlun
& Belor.What a glorious approximation is your height of Chumalarito Waugh’s measurements.

p.add:
This has been a sad season in India – I have lost & an
Uncle – Williams of the Geol. Geological Survey
with whom I travelled 3 months both dead of Fever – McLelland, who went to
carry on the survey, took fever & had to break up the camp. My early friend Gardner
at Ceylon a first rate Naturalist is
dead died last month .
& poor Thomson’s constitution
is shattered. Hence I write in low spirits –
